"Phenomena of Color',
Senior Essay Topic
----The topic of the essay required
of all Seniors in the Natural Science
Group for 1936-37 is "The Phenomenon of Color," according to an announcement made through the
Dean's Office.
The essay is to include "The
phenomenon of color: what causes
it, how it is perceived, how it is
distributed in the universe, how it
is made use of in scientific work,
what effect it has on living organisms, and what its practical value
is in the arts and sciences."
The papers, which are to be between 3000 and 5000 words should
be handed to Dr. R. P. Cowles,
Chairman of the Natural Science
Group, on or before March 1, 1937.

Dr. Broadus Mitchell, Associate Professor of Political Economy at the
Johns Hopkins University, acted as
toastmaster at a gathering of the
Socialist Party of Baltimore last Wednesday night when Mayor Daniel W.
Hoan, Socialist Mayor of Milwaukee,
spoke.
"The most interesting development
of the meeting," said Dr. Mitchell, was
that there were a good number of nonSocialists there who were interested
in Mayor Hoan's administrative
success".
Mayor Hoan has lowered the debt of
Milwaukee by investing the city's
money in United States Government
Bonds at an interest rate of 5 per
cent. This rate, much above that of
commercial banks, has given the city
enough surplus to partially reduce the
city deficit, and at the present rate
this deficit will completely be wiped
out within seven years.

As the curtain rises for another
year of activities on the Hopkins campus, the debating team under the
leadership of Mr. Earl Reeves Wasserman hopes to enjoy as successful a
season this year as they have enjoyed
in previous years. The debating team
captain, Mr. Phillip Grosman, delivered an explanatory address before
the freshmen and sophomores telling
of the advantages and pleasures which
prospective members of the team may
enjoy.
The debating team will have a private meeting of all members of last
years squad ths week. A notice will
later e printed in The NEWS-LETTER
encouraging prospective members to
try out. The team wishes that the student body will cooperate with them in
forming a strong team and in providing a fairly large audience for each
debate.

the Giant's Causeway, Belfast, and
Dublin, and then took time to kiss the
Blarney Stone, ended his junket. Before leaving Ireland, however, he

article concerning the discovery of

The first meeting of the Johns
Hopkins Musical Association, which
supports the Johns Hopkins Orchestra,
will be held in the main hall of the
Peabody Institute, at 8 P. M. on
Tuesday, October sixth. All members
of the University who find interest in
music are invited to join. The first
rehearsal is scheduled for the same
evening.
Information is to be made available
before the first rehearsal, and may
be obtained from Mr. Philip S. Morgan, 514 St. Paul Street. Phone Vernon

For two hours Saturday in glorious football weather, the Blue Jay
girkkiers engaged in a hard, fast
scrimmage. Actually, this was the
first real test the gridiron hopefuls
have faced and it was of invaluable
aid to the members of the coaching
staff.
Play was confined in the main to
straight football. Off tackle slant, center plunges and sweeping end runs
were employed consistently. However,
on certain occasions, cleverly conceived laterals and forward passes
were brought into play.
Action For All
Every uniformed candidate saw
action in this make-believe contest.
Several individuals brought to light
their football potentialities; while
others aptly illustrated their apparent flaws.
Fortified with a charging aggressive
line, the first string backfield turned
in a creditable exhibition. Driving low
and fast, blocking briskly, they reeled
off a number of long gains on the batling second eleven.
Kicking Good
In at. least one department, the Blue
Jay huskies won't be outclassed,
two
with

kickin.
men, Kahl and Greene, whose long,
high spirals carry far down the
field, the Jays should hold their own
against the best punters of the opposition. For gaining point after
touchdowns, the Jays have Baetjer,
whose accurate place-kicking would
fulfill the dreams of any gridiron

Practice Daily
As the curtain rises on the current
football season, some 59 candidates
are putting in daily appearances at
the practice field. Striving fervently
to acquire coveted varsity berths the
football hopefuls are doing their utmost to favorably impress the high
and mighty coaching staff. The sight
of footballs spiralling through the
air, the thud of bodies hitting the
turf, the shrieking exhortations of
coaches all present testimony that
the active organization of a Blue
Jay eleven is under way at Homewood
Field.
Blessed with a plethora of good material, Coach Manonce is hopeful of
turning out one of the strongest
Hopkins teams of recent years.
The return of a number of veteran
backs, led by Captain Ted Graziano,
and the appearance of several new
promising candidates presage a versatile and capable backfield. As for the
line, Ed Lotz, line coach, does not feel
the slightest doubt concerning the
potentialities of his charges.

Attractive Card
Arranged
A rapid glance at the 1936 schedule reveals that games have been arranged with teams of approximately
the same calibre and strength as the
Hopkins aggregation. High pressure
elevens, suspected of being subsidized
have been dropped from the list of
Blue Jay opponents. The reasons for
this action are obvious. The Malonee
squad does not seek to march through
a victorious season by season of a
schedule of set-ups. But certainly the

The teams which will participate
this year are all definitely organized,
all of them, except the freshman
teams, being carried over from last
year. Both teams which tied for first
place last year, namely the SeniorGas-Civils, captained this year by
Weisman, and the Senior Business,
captained by Reynolds, will participate again this year. The New Jersey
All-Stars, led by Carl Resin and Harold Zheutlin, who took second place
last year, is determined to win the
medals this year. This team was
the medalist in basketball and runner
up in baseball last year, losing first
place in baseball to the Senior Dorms.
Strong Clubs
Other strong teams which will also
strive for victory are the Senior Mechanicals led •by Gallowey, the Senior
Electricals led by Dicker, the Junior
All-Stars led by Josh Perman, and the
Senior Businessmen led by Reynolds
and Geraldsienis. The freshmen teams
are still dark horses but are expected
to provide plenty of competition for
the upperclassmen.
Baer Expects Much
Reuben Baer who expects to make
this his banner year as director of
the intramural competitions, promises very good equipment for all.

Sport Light
Our new backfield coach—dear al'
"Wats," that's him . . . Experienced
an active scholastic athletic career at
Poly—football, baseball, and track .. .
Graduated in '25 .. . Entered Hopkins
to establish a name for himself on
the gridiron and track . . . Played
at "half" and full for three years as
an excellent left handed passing and
blocking back . . . On the cinderpath
Wats ran a fine "100" and "220" . . .
Received sheepskin as a full fledged
engineer in '28—a three year man ...
Wats and "Mal" Gardner "do or
died" for dear old Johnny Hopkins on
the same team during '26, 27, and '28
. . . Both hold the distinction the first
and last Hopkins team to beat Maryland since 1915 (score 14-13) . ..
Previous to his recent appointment
as backfield coach at Homewood,
Wats tutered the Boy's Latin Gridders . . . His warm reception is indicative how our boys took to Wats
—just like a duck tages to water. . .
Let's take our hats off to Wats—
a peachy guy.

"Phenomena of Color',
Senior Essay Topic
----The topic of the essay required
of all Seniors in the Natural Science
Group for 1936-37 is "The Phenomenon of Color," according to an announcement made through the
Dean's Office.
The essay is to include "The
phenomenon of color: what causes
it, how it is perceived, how it is
distributed in the universe, how it
is made use of in scientific work,
what effect it has on living organisms, and what its practical value
is in the arts and sciences."
The papers, which are to be between 3000 and 5000 words should
be handed to Dr. R. P. Cowles,
Chairman of the Natural Science
Group, on or before March 1, 1937.

Dr. Broadus Mitchell, Associate Professor of Political Economy at the
Johns Hopkins University, acted as
toastmaster at a gathering of the
Socialist Party of Baltimore last Wednesday night when Mayor Daniel W.
Hoan, Socialist Mayor of Milwaukee,
spoke.
"The most interesting development
of the meeting," said Dr. Mitchell, was
that there were a good number of nonSocialists there who were interested
in Mayor Hoan's administrative
success".
Mayor Hoan has lowered the debt of
Milwaukee by investing the city's
money in United States Government
Bonds at an interest rate of 5 per
cent. This rate, much above that of
commercial banks, has given the city
enough surplus to partially reduce the
city deficit, and at the present rate
this deficit will completely be wiped
out within seven years.

As the curtain rises for another
year of activities on the Hopkins campus, the debating team under the
leadership of Mr. Earl Reeves Wasserman hopes to enjoy as successful a
season this year as they have enjoyed
in previous years. The debating team
captain, Mr. Phillip Grosman, delivered an explanatory address before
the freshmen and sophomores telling
of the advantages and pleasures which
prospective members of the team may
enjoy.
The debating team will have a private meeting of all members of last
years squad ths week. A notice will
later e printed in The NEWS-LETTER
encouraging prospective members to
try out. The team wishes that the student body will cooperate with them in
forming a strong team and in providing a fairly large audience for each
debate.

Hopkins Musical Association, which
supports the Johns Hopkins Orchestra,
will be held in the main hall of the
Peabody Institute, at 8 P. M. on
Tuesday, October sixth. All members
of the University who find interest in
music are invited to join. The first
rehearsal is scheduled for the same
evening.

be obtained from Mr. Philip S. Morgan, 514 St. Paul Street. Phone Vernon

For two hours Saturday in glorious football weather, the Blue Jay
girkkiers engaged in a hard, fast
scrimmage. Actually, this was the
first real test the gridiron hopefuls
have faced and it was of invaluable
aid to the members of the coaching
staff.
Play was confined in the main to
straight football. Off tackle slant, center plunges and sweeping end runs
were employed consistently. However,
on certain occasions, cleverly conceived laterals and forward passes
were brought into play.
Action For All
Every uniformed candidate saw
action in this make-believe contest.
Several individuals brought to light
their football potentialities; while
others aptly illustrated their apparent flaws.
Fortified with a charging aggressive
line, the first string backfield turned
in a creditable exhibition. Driving low
and fast, blocking briskly, they reeled
off a number of long gains on the batling second eleven.
Kicking Good
In at. least one department, the Blue
Jay huskies won't be outclassed,
two
with

kickin.
men, Kahl and Greene, whose long,
high spirals carry far down the
field, the Jays should hold their own
against the best punters of the opposition. For gaining point after
touchdowns, the Jays have Baetjer,
whose accurate place-kicking would
fulfill the dreams of any gridiron

Practice Daily
As the curtain rises on the current
football season, some 59 candidates
are putting in daily appearances at
the practice field. Striving fervently
to acquire coveted varsity berths the
football hopefuls are doing their utmost to favorably impress the high
and mighty coaching staff. The sight
of footballs spiralling through the
air, the thud of bodies hitting the
turf, the shrieking exhortations of
coaches all present testimony that
the active organization of a Blue
Jay eleven is under way at Homewood
Field.
Blessed with a plethora of good material, Coach Manonce is hopeful of
turning out one of the strongest
Hopkins teams of recent years.
The return of a number of veteran
backs, led by Captain Ted Graziano,
and the appearance of several new
promising candidates presage a versatile and capable backfield. As for the
line, Ed Lotz, line coach, does not feel
the slightest doubt concerning the
potentialities of his charges.

Attractive Card
Arranged
A rapid glance at the 1936 schedule reveals that games have been arranged with teams of approximately
the same calibre and strength as the
Hopkins aggregation. High pressure
elevens, suspected of being subsidized
have been dropped from the list of
Blue Jay opponents. The reasons for
this action are obvious. The Malonee
squad does not seek to march through
a victorious season by season of a
schedule of set-ups. But certainly the

The teams which will participate
this year are all definitely organized,
all of them, except the freshman
teams, being carried over from last
year. Both teams which tied for first
place last year, namely the SeniorGas-Civils, captained this year by
Weisman, and the Senior Business,
captained by Reynolds, will participate again this year. The New Jersey
All-Stars, led by Carl Resin and Harold Zheutlin, who took second place
last year, is determined to win the
medals this year. This team was
the medalist in basketball and runner
up in baseball last year, losing first
place in baseball to the Senior Dorms.
Strong Clubs
Other strong teams which will also
strive for victory are the Senior Mechanicals led •by Gallowey, the Senior
Electricals led by Dicker, the Junior
All-Stars led by Josh Perman, and the
Senior Businessmen led by Reynolds
and Geraldsienis. The freshmen teams
are still dark horses but are expected
to provide plenty of competition for
the upperclassmen.
Baer Expects Much
Reuben Baer who expects to make
this his banner year as director of
the intramural competitions, promises very good equipment for all.

Sport Light
Our new backfield coach—dear al'
"Wats," that's him . . . Experienced
an active scholastic athletic career at
Poly—football, baseball, and track .. .
Graduated in '25 .. . Entered Hopkins
to establish a name for himself on
the gridiron and track . . . Played
at "half" and full for three years as
an excellent left handed passing and
blocking back . . . On the cinderpath
Wats ran a fine "100" and "220" . . .
Received sheepskin as a full fledged
engineer in '28—a three year man ...
Wats and "Mal" Gardner "do or
died" for dear old Johnny Hopkins on
the same team during '26, 27, and '28
. . . Both hold the distinction the first
and last Hopkins team to beat Maryland since 1915 (score 14-13) . ..
Previous to his recent appointment
as backfield coach at Homewood,
Wats tutered the Boy's Latin Gridders . . . His warm reception is indicative how our boys took to Wats
—just like a duck tages to water. . .
Let's take our hats off to Wats—
a peachy guy.

Missing from Saturday's tussle was
Capthe sturdy Jay back and leader,
suffering
tain Ted Graziano. Still
from a physical infirmity, the stocky
captain was unable to participate, but
during this week he will once again
be out for each practice session.
Only one casualty marked the day's
